msIdentifier.repository: The John Rylands Research Institute and Library

msContents.summary: Volume containing Juzʿ 4 of the Qurʾān (Sūrah 3:92-4:23). It is written in large golden letters, in a Maghribi or African hand, midway between Kūfi and Naskhi.

msItem.title: al-Qurʾān
القران
msItem.note: Taʿawwudh in illuminated panel at the beginning of the Sūrah: اعوذ بالله من الشيطان (I seek refuge in Allah from Satan).

msItem.title: Sūrat an-Nisā
سورة النساء
msItem.note: Folio 87b: title of sūrah in Kūfi characters.
Formula at the end, on folio 117b: كمل الرابع بحمد الله ('The fourth [juz] is complete, thank God').

supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in the upper left corner of each recto. Earlier foliation in golden in in the upper right margin of the verso side up to folio 16b. In reality it is 118 folios because folio 66 is duplicated.

layoutDesc.layout: Hair and flesh sides are distinguishable. Uniform layout. Ruling for inner and outer margins in red ink.

handDesc.handNote: Maghribi or African hand, midway between Kūfi and Naskhi script; written in gold, with vocalisation in blue ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: Folios 1b-2a: illuminated carpet pages with geometrical patterns.
Gold ornaments mark the section divisions.
Verse markers in margin: three circles of equal size touching forming a triangle, in gold, decorated with smaller red and blue circles (e.g. folio 5a).
Teardrop-shaped illuminated ornaments marking every fifth(?) verse (e.g. folios 5b, 13b, 21b, 29a, 35a, 41a, 51b, 59b, 66aa, 83b, 92a, 107a).
Larger, illuminated roundels marking every tenth(?) verse with the word عشر in the middle (folios 16a, 26a, 31b, 38a, 56a, 63a, 70a, 78b, 87a, 97a)

binding.p: 19th-century leather binding incorporating pieces of an earlier binding on the front and back covers. This earlier binding is gold-tooled. cover
Pencil note on flyleaf ia: Binding repaired by Mr Wilson of Messis Durham and Wilson. October 1963. F.T.

history.provenance: Formerly part of the collection of a Chevalier J. Ferrão de Castel-Branco (or Castelbranco), member of the Royal Asiatic Society. Purchased by James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford via Quaritch at the Castelbranco sale, Lisbon 1883; see Catalogue d'une collection de livres rares et de manuscrits preceieux dont la vente aura lieu a Lisbonne (Lisbonne: Typographie de Veuve Sousa Neves, 1883), page 27, Lot 354 bis.

provenance.p: Formerly in the collection of Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford (1812–1880) Crawford, Alexander Crawford Lindsay, 1812-1880. Bibliotheca Lindesiana bookplate on the back pastedown.
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) Rylands, Enriqueta, 1843–1908 in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847–1913) Crawford, James Ludovic Lindsay, Earl of, 1847–1913 .

acquisition.p: Bequeathed by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1908 to The John Rylands Library.

recordHist.source: Description based on A. Mingana, Catalogue of the Arabic Manuscripts in the John Rylands Library Manchester (Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1934).
